questions.text: Which of the following best describes the drainage pathway of the sinus that is marked with an arrow in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Sphenoethmoidal recess

options.label: B
options.text: Superior meatus

options.label: C
options.text: Middle meatus

options.label: D
options.text: Ethmoid bulla

questions.explanation:
Sinus

Appearance

Full Development

Maxillary

Present at birth

15-18 years

Ethmoid

Present at birth

12-14 years

3-5 years

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient complains of difficulty breathing through their nose. He also reports complaints of smell perception. The otolaryngologist decides to perform both the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) and rhinomanometry. Which of the following statements regarding these tests is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The UPSIT helps to understand if the patient's ability to perceive smell is good or bad.

options.label: B
options.text: Rhinomanometry is a subjective function test to assess nasal airflow.

options.label: C
options.text: In the UPSIT, the patient is given scratch cards of odorous stimuli and asked to write down the smell.

options.label: D
options.text: Rhinomanometry results can be used to check for improvement after nasal surgery.

questions.correct_answer: B. Rhinomanometry is a subjective function test to assess nasal airflow.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the airflow dynamics during respiration through the nose is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Mouth breathing is not present in newborns

options.label: B
options.text: Very little air passes through olfactory region of nose

options.label: C
options.text: Maximum airflow during quiet respiration occurs through inferior turbinate

options.label: D
options.text: Friction during expiration causes the air to form eddies at the nasal valve , ventilating the sinuses.

questions.correct_answer: C. Maximum airflow during quiet respiration occurs through inferior turbinate

questions.text: A junior resident is studying the anatomy of the medial wall of the orbit. Which of the following statements about this structure is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The medial walls of both orbits run parallel to each other and form the lateral walls of ethmoid air cell.

options.label: B
options.text: The medial wall is formed by parts of the sphenoid, ethmoid, lacrimal, and maxillary bones.

options.label: C
options.text: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal foramina are located at the junction of the roof and the lateral wall of the orbit.

options.label: D
options.text: The optic canal is situated at the posterior junction of the medial wall and the roof of the orbit.

questions.correct_answer: C. The anterior and posterior ethmoidal foramina are located at the junction of the roof and the lateral wall of the orbit.
questions.explanation:
Features of Medial Wall of Orbit

Composition

Formed by parts of the sphenoid bone, orbital surface of the ethmoid bone, lacrimal bone, and frontal process of the maxilla.

                 Fig: Composition of Medial Wall of Orbit

Orientation

Runs parallel to the contralateral medial wall; forms lateral wall of nasal cavity

Ethmoidal Air Cells

Air-filled spaces in the ethmoid bone portion of the medial wall

Foramina
  • Anterior Ethmoidal Foramen
  • Posterior Ethmoidal Foramen
  • Optic canal

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the venous drainage of the nose is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The venous networks parallel the arterial supply in their distribution.

options.label: B
options.text: The fronto-median area drains to the facial vein, while the orbito-palpebral area drains to the ophthalmic vein.

options.label: C
options.text: The facial vein originates as the angular vein, which is formed by the confluence of the supratrochlear and supraorbital veins.

options.label: D
options.text: Infections in the upper lip and nose can potentially spread to the cavernous sinus due to a valveless venous connection.

questions.correct_answer: A. The venous networks parallel the arterial supply in their distribution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the lining membrane of the internal nose is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The vestibule is lined by skin containing hair, hair follicles, and sebaceous glands.

options.label: B
options.text: The olfactory region covers the lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity.

options.label: C
options.text: The respiratory region's mucous membrane is thickest over nasal conchae.

options.label: D
options.text: The olfactory region's membrane is paler in color compared to other regions.

questions.correct_answer: B. The olfactory region covers the lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity.
questions.explanation:
Region

Location

Lining

Key Feature

Vestibule

(Option A)

Entrance of the nose
  • Skin containing hair, hair follicles, and sebaceous glands
  • Epithelium- Stratified squamous epithelium

Acts as initial filter for air entering the nose

Olfactory Region

Upper one-third of lateral wall, corresponding part of nasal septum, and roof of nasal cavity

Olfactory epithelium

Specialized for detecting odors, membrane is paler in color (Option D)

Respiratory Region

Lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells

Variable thickness (thickest over nasal conchae) (Option C), highly vascular, contains erectile tissue

options.text: Sellar

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.text: A 50-year-old male complains of deep-seated headaches and visual disturbances. Imaging reveals a sphenoid sinus mucocele compressing adjacent structures. Which of the following is most likely to be compressed by this mucocele?

options.label: A
options.text: Optic nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Mandibular nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Middle meningeal artery

options.label: D
options.text: Superior sagittal sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding the ethmoid air cells?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior ethmoid air cells drain into the middle meatus.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the last of the paranasal sinuses to fully develop.

options.label: C
options.text: They are closely related to the orbit.

options.label: D
options.text: The posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus.

questions.correct_answer: B. They are the last of the paranasal sinuses to fully develop.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Bulla ethmoidalisOstiomeatal complex

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Middle Meatus a) Sphenoid sinus 2. Superior Meatus b) Frontal sinus 3. Sphenoethmoidal Recess c) Posterior Ethmoid sinus
questions.explanation:
MEATUS

DRAINAGE OF SINUS

Middle Meatus
  • Ostiomeatal Unit or Complex of frontal, anterior ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses drain.
  • Common drainage pathway of anterior group of sinuses.

Superior Meatus

Posterior Ethmoid sinus drains.

Sphenoethmoidal Recess

Sphenoid sinus drains.

Inferior Meatus

The nasolacrimal duct opens here.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the lateral nasal wall is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The lateral nasal wall has turbinates: inferior, middle, superior, and supreme.

options.label: B
options.text: Spaces below the turbinates are called sinuses.

options.label: C
options.text: The turbinates include inferior, middle, superior, and lateral.

options.label: D
options.text: Spaces below the turbinates are meatuses: superior, middle, and supreme.

questions.correct_answer: A. The lateral nasal wall has turbinates: inferior, middle, superior, and supreme.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the medial wall of the nose is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the internal carotid system.

options.label: B
options.text: The sphenopalatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system.

options.label: C
options.text: Kiesselbach’s plexus is formed by the anastomosis of the anterior & posterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, and infraorbital arteries.

options.label: D
options.text: The columellar septum is formed by the medial crura of the alar cartilages.

questions.correct_answer: C. Kiesselbach’s plexus is formed by the anastomosis of the anterior & posterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, and infraorbital arteries.
questions.explanation:
Medial wall of nose (Nasal septum)

Components of Nasal septum:

Columellar Septum
  • Formed by the columella containing medial crura of alar cartilages. (Option D)
  • United by fibrous tissue and covered by skin.

Membranous Septum
  • Composed of a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support.
  • Located between the columella and the caudal border of the septal cartilage.
  • Freely movable from side to side.

Septum Proper
  • Consists of osteocartilaginous framework covered with nasal mucous membrane.
  • Principal parts:
    • Perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone.
    • Vomer bone.
    • Septal (quadrilateral) cartilage between the ethmoid and vomer.
  • Minor contributions from surrounding bones: nasal bones, frontal bone, sphenoid, palatine bones, maxilla, and anterior nasal spine.

Fig: Septum Proper

Nasal Septum Blood Supply:

Internal Carotid System
  1. Anterior Ethmoidal Artery: (Option A)
    • A branch of the ophthalmic artery.
  2. Posterior Ethmoidal Artery:
    • A branch of the ophthalmic artery.

External Carotid System
  1. Sphenopalatine Artery (SPA): (Option B)
    • A branch of the maxillary artery.
    • Gives off nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  2. Septal Branch of Greater Palatine Artery:
    • A branch of the maxillary artery.
  3. Septal Branch of Superior Labial Artery:
    • A branch of the facial artery.

Little’s Area (Kiesselbach’s Plexus)
  • Located at Anterior-inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule.
  • Formed by the anastomosis of: (Option C)
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery
    • Sphenopalatine artery
    • Greater palatine artery
    • Septal branch of the superior labial artery
  • Commonest site for nosebleeds (epistaxis).
  • Most common cause: Trauma/Nose Picking
  • Most common cause in adults: Hypertension
  • Site where "bleeding polypus" (haemangioma) of the nasal septum can originate.
  • Venous plexus that is present at the posteroinferior portion of the septum is known as Woodruff's plexus.

Fig: Blood supply of Nasal Septum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the nose are true? The anterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the nasal bones. The floor of the nose is formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. The posterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the body of the sphenoid bone. The anterior three-fourths of the floor of the nose is formed by the palatine process of the maxilla. The posterior one-fourth of the floor of the nose is formed by the horizontal part of the sphenoid bone.

options.label: A
options.text: Only 2

questions.explanation:
Roof of the nose

Floor of the nose
  • Anterior Sloping Part: Formed by the nasal bones. (Statement 1)
  • Posterior Sloping Part: Formed by the body of the sphenoid bone. (Statement 3)
  • Middle Horizontal Part: Formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (passage of olfactory nerves into the nasal cavity). (Statement 2)
  • Anterior Three-Fourths: Formed by the palatine process of the maxilla. (Statement 4)
  • Posterior One-Fourth: Formed by the horizontal part of the palatine bone. (Statement 5)

questions.text: What is the primary function of the nasal valve in the nasal respiratory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide resonance to the voice

options.label: B
options.text: Regulating airflow resistance and airflow dynamics

options.label: C
options.text: Modulating the temperature and humidity of inspired air

options.label: D
options.text: Sensing and processing olfactory stimuli

questions.correct_answer: B. Regulating airflow resistance and airflow dynamics

questions.text: Match the following in relation to the internal anatomy of the nose. a. Anterior 1. Nasal septum b. Lateral 2. Choanae c. Medial 3. Vestibule d. Posterior 4. Lateral wall of nose
questions.explanation:
Anterior

Vestibule

Posterior

Choanae

Roof

Roof of the nose separates the nasal cavity from the anterior cranial fossa

Floor

The floor of the nose separates the nasal cavity from the oral cavity

Medial

Septum: separates the right side of the nose from the left side

Lateral

The lateral wall of the nose
